tossups.question: Conceptual artist Rob Pruitt has created daily paintings of this person from images retrieved via Google Image Search. This person dons novelty sunglasses in the cover image of the 2018 photobook Shade. A widely circulated image of this person was adapted from a photograph taken by Mannie Garcia. Cicely Tyson and Miles Davis stand outside this person's house in a painting by Henry Taylor that appeared on the cover of Art in America. A book offering an "An Intimate Portrait" of this person was published by (*) Pete Souza, his official photographer. This man's shoes seem to float in the leafy background in a portrait in which he is seated on a chair by artist Kehinde Wiley. Shepard Fairey's "Hope" poster depicts, for 10 points, what former US President?

This country was protected from losing 850 million dollars after analysts at the New York Fed noted that a Sri Lankan group called the "Shalika Foundation" was misspelled. David Montero's book Kickback records how Siemens paid 5 million dollars in bribes to run this country's incredibly inefficient Teletalk mobile system; the bribes were used to finance the terrorist group JMB. In February 2016, thieves stole 81 million dollars from this country's central bank in a hack against the (*) Swift payments system likely orchestrated by North Korea. Walmart finally agreed to a labor accord in this country after a 2013 incident at Rana Plaza. In July 2020, a quarter of this country flooded a few months after it was hit by Super Cyclone Amphan. For 10 points, name this country where over a thousand people were killed in a 2013 garment factory collapse in Dhaka.
tossups.answer: Bangladesh [or People's Republic of Bangladesh; or Gônoprojatontri Bangladesh]

tossups.question: This company funded astroturf groups through its Let Nothing Go strategy. Felipe Amin Filomeno documented the royalty system that this company established to get around Paraguay's weak patent laws. Its executive William Heydens pressured Critical Reviews in Toxicology to publish a biased rebuttal to claims made against it by the IARC. In 2018, a jury ordered this company to pay California groundskeeper Dewayne Johnson 289 million dollars in damages. Eight years earlier, it bought a startup that used (*) RNA to destroy bee parasites called Beelogics. It's not Dow, but lawsuits filed by this company allegedly led to hundreds of thousands of suicides in rural India. This company, now owned by Bayer, is being sued by people who developed non-Hodgkin lymphoma from glyphosate. For 10 points, name this company that makes Roundup-Ready genetically engineered crops.

A then-84-year-old resident of this city from a Lebanese family spent a night in jail after refusing a judge's order that he finish new ramps for an expressway. In 2012, voters in this city defeated Proposal 6, which would have made it harder to build a new bridge. Black Panthers in this city formed an alliance with Manuel Moroun, a recently deceased billionaire whose privately owned bridge was threatened by a new project to be named for a local (*) hockey star. CEO James Hackett announced a plan to redevelop a Beaux Arts building in this city into his company's new Corktown campus; that train station appears on the cover of Yves Marchand and Romain Meffre's book about this city's "ruins." The Ambassador Bridge will soon be supplemented by the Gordie Howe International Bridge to connect this city to Windsor, Ontario. For 10 points, name this most populous city in Michigan.

At one event in this institution, women but not men were permitted to use a special Wi-Fi router to buy land in the successor countries to Yugoslavia, an idea of Irena Haiduk. In conjunction with an event at this institution, Anicka Yi went to the Amazon Rainforest in search of the "Flavor Genome." In 2017, visitors to this institution could strap on VR goggles and witness Jordan Wolfson savagely beating a man to death with a baseball bat. For much of that same event at this institution, (*) Parker Bright physically protested Dana Schutz's appropriation of Emmett Till. A building originally constructed for this institution will soon be the temporary home of the Frick Collection. In 2015, this museum moved from a building designed by Marcel Breuer to a new facility in the West Village. For 10 points, name this New York museum that stages a noted biennial.
tossups.answer: Whitney Museum of American Art [or the Whitney; accept Whitney Biennial]

tossups.question: Baumgartner, Epp, and Shoub examined 20 million of these events in North Carolina over more than a decade, concluding that they imposed a high cost of alienation. In a unanimous 1996 opinion in Whren v. US, the Supreme Court approved a form of these events that started on pretextual basis. A recent book by historian Sarah A. Seo ("SAY-oh") argued that these events reshaped American jurisprudence on the Fourth Amendment. In the case of Ohio v. Robinette, the Supreme Court held that, during these events, it was "unrealistic" to require that people be (*) informed that they had a right to refuse a search. In an extension of the Terry doctrine, the 1990 Sitz case upheld the right for these events to include field sobriety checks. For 10 points, name these events in which motorists are pulled over by police officers.
tossups.answer: traffic stops [accept answers like being pulled over by police before the end; accept anything involving police interactions with motorists; prompt on police stops or police searches; prompt on stop and frisk by asking "during what events are those frisks happening?"; do not accept “arrests”] (The first line is about Suspect Citizens. Seo's book is Policing the Open Road.)

tossups.question: The QNX operating system was developed at this country’s flagship technical university, the alma mater of PHP creator Rasmus Lerdorf. Nasma Ahmed led the opposition to one project in this country backed by CEO Dan Doctoroff until it was cancelled during the COVID-19 pandemic. This country’s economy was once dominated by a telecom company whose most valuable IP was stolen by hackers working for Huáwéi. An independent data trust would have supervised a project in (*) Quayside in this country’s largest city until Sidewalk Labs pulled out of the venture. Telecom firm Nortel was based in this country, as was the maker of the Pearl smartphone. For 10 points, Alphabet’s Sidewalk Labs abandoned plans to build a smart city in what country, home to the University of Waterloo and Blackberry?

The narrator of a novel set in this state sees his high school girlfriend Madison screwing around with a lacrosse player in a parking lot of an Olive Garden. This state titles a 2018 novel in which friends such as Bill Ashcraft and Tina Ross reconvene on the sixth anniversary of soldier Rick Brinklan's death. Parts of a novel set in this state are narrated by a female mountain lion; the rest is a stream-of-consciousness from a mother-of-four married to a man named Leo. It's not Kentucky, but an author who later made it to (*) Yale Law School was raised in this state’s city of Middletown. J. D. Vance of Hillbilly Elegy fame grew up in this state, which is the setting of a thousand-page novel consisting of mostly a single sentence, Lucy Ellmann’s Ducks, Newburyport. For 10 points, name this state whose prisons were examined in Season 3 of the Serial podcast, set in Cleveland.
tossups.answer: Ohio [or OH] (Stephen Markley wrote the novel Ohio.)

tossups.question: The final section of a 2019 novel by this author shifts the focus to a group of rifugiati in Venice. In that same novel by this author, a Brooklyn-based rare bookseller has his life changed when he visits a shrine in the Sundarbans built by the title 17th-century merchant, Bonduki Sadagar. This author adapted some lectures on why so little contemporary fiction addressed the problem of climate change into the book The Great Derangement. An earlier novel by this author centers on an orphan named Rajkumar who becomes successful in the teak business by working with Saya John and opens with a dispute over timber between the British and the Burmese King Thebaw ("thee-baw"). The best-known series by this author of The (*) Glass Palace depicts Deeti, the wife of a worker in the Ghazipur Opium Factory. For 10 points, name this Indian author of the Ibis Trilogy.
tossups.answer: Amitav Ghosh (The early clues are about Gun Island.)

tossups.question: As a young lawyer at Christian Fisher, this man won a record settlement for a wrongful arrest of a hairdresser. This one-time standup comic was given a Number 44 Mets jersey in honor of the bus route that his father drove. This man almost lost a seat in Parliament in a tight race against Liberal Democrat candidate Nasser Butt and Conservative Mark Clarke. His policies have included a Toxicity Charge imposed on (*) polluting vehicles to go along with congestion pricing. He won his current position by defeating Zac Goldsmith. This man’s backers yelled "Racist" at the then-Prime Minister after the PM criticized Suliman Gani. After terrorist attacks at Borough Market and a noted tourist bridge, Donald Trump falsely claimed that this man told his city, "no reason to be alarmed!" For 10 points, name this Mayor of London.

A man in this book claims that his collection of sports memorabilia is worth 15 million dollars and laments that his "laboratory" has had an "undistinguished beginning" in a journal entry about Mr. and Mrs. W. During a media storm in this book, a woman named Anita stares at a copy of The Denver Post in her driveway. In 2016, the author of this book said "How dare I promote it when its credibility is down the toilet?" after The (*) Washington Post published an article analyzing property records from 1980 to 1988 and questioning its subject's honesty. This book, which is similar to its author's Thy Neighbor's Wife, records how a man created an "observation platform" with special air vents that he used to spy on people. For 10 points, Gerald Foos is profiled in what book by Gay Talese ("tuh-LEEZ") about a man who peeps on guests in the title place of accommodation?

A mob in this novel brags about how "We are moral men. We are principled men" after not lynching a driver who turns out to be telling the truth that he is transporting potatoes instead of cows. One character in this novel takes up smoking after getting a job at Pantaloons and is the daughter of a woman who is assaulted while buying food at an illegal night market. That same character in this novel writes a fateful Facebook post about police complicity and is betrayed by her former (*) phys ed teacher, now a politician. Lovely, a hijra character in this novel, achieves her goal of becoming a film star after gaining viral fame defending the protagonist, a Muslim woman named Jivan who is accused of being involved in a train bombing. For 10 points, name this acclaimed 2020 debut novel by Megha Majumdar.

Like ECOWAS, this organization suspended Mali's membership after an August 2020 coup, in keeping with the principles of the charter it adopted in 2005 in Antananarivo. This organization promotes an international celebration on March 20th to commemorate the founding of its predecessor, the ACCT, at the 1970 Niamey Conference, which was spearheaded by Habib Bourguiba ("boor-GHEE-ba") and Léopold Senghor. It was first led by Egypt's Boutros Boutros-Ghali and is currently led by Rwanda's Louise Mushikiwabo. Often compared to the (*) Commonwealth of Nations, about 50 percent of people represented by this Europe-based organization live in Africa, where it promotes its goals by sponsoring lycées ("lee-SAY"). For 10 points, what international organization regulates and promotes the use of the French language?
tossups.answer: La Francophonie [or Organisation internationale de la Francophonie, or OIF, or International Organisation of La Francophonie]

tossups.question: Susan Levenstein defended this condition's role against falling research interest since the 1970s in "The Very Model of a Modern Etiology." A book about this condition discusses aiming anesthetic darts at subordinate males like Gary and Kenneth and explains its inhibition of testosterone. It’s not pain or hypertension, but inequities cause Black women to experience this condition more often in Arline Geronimus's weathering hypothesis. Fieldwork with olive baboons informed an "acclaimed guide" to this condition by Robert (*) Sapolsky, which discusses Joseph Brady's experiments on shocking "executive monkeys" and argues that a putative consequence rarely affects zebras. Chronic levels of this condition increase allostatic load. Barry Marshall drank a beaker of H. pylori to show that it, not this condition, caused ulcers. For 10 points, what condition causes the HPA axis to release glucocorticoids like cortisol?
tossups.answer: stress [or stress response; or word forms like stressors; accept distress; accept stress hormones; accept allostatic load before read; accept general adaptation syndrome; do not accept or prompt on "PTSD" or "post-traumatic stress disorder"; prompt on "fight-or-flight"; prompt on ulcers or gastritis or Why Zebras Don't Get Ulcers or "Ulcers in Executive Monkeys" etc. by asking "what psychological condition was once thought to be the main cause of ulcers?"; prompt on aging by asking "as a consequence of what psychological condition?"; accept The Acclaimed Guide to Stress, Stress-Related Diseases, and Coping]

tossups.question: Protesters who sarcastically placed flowers at a regional office owned by this company inspired the meme of "illegal flower throwing." This company published a drawing game called Guess My Sketch to attract Chinese audiences on WeChat. This company launched Operation Helm's Deep after discovering that its most important source code had been hacked. This company once operated a service nicknamed the (*) Dragon Index that had a disclaimer indicating that some results were censored. This company is the subject of Steven Levy's book In the Plex. A Russian-born co-founder of this company declared, "Our objection is to those forces of totalitarianism" to justify ending business in one country. For 10 points, name this American search company that pulled out of China.

The Supreme Court ruled that states couldn't impose more stringent regulations on these things than federal guidelines in the 2008 Riegel decision. In one of the largest tax inversions in history, the leading US maker of these things merged with Ireland's Covidien. High-risk Class III examples of these things largely avoid regulation thanks to a loophole allowing "upgrades" to any version used before 1976. From 2013 until 2019, a 2.3% excise tax was placed on the sale of these things in the US. Class I and II versions of these things, once taxed by the (*) Affordable Care Act, only have to be "cleared" by a regulator. Vaginal meshes, like all examples of these things, are barely regulated by the FDA. They are made by companies like Medtronic. For 10 points, name these things that include artificial hips and pacemakers.
tossups.answer: medical devices [or medical implants; prompt on devices by asking "for what purpose?"; anti-prompt on more specific answers like pacemakers or insulin pumps or artificial hips or prostheses] (The Supreme Court case was Riegel v. Medtronic, Inc.)

bonuses.leadin: Dr. Alexander Khoruts has warned that a "cartel" of companies like Rebiotix and Vedanta Biosciences will dominate this type of medicine if the FDA changes its policies. For 10 points each:
answers: fecal microbiota transplants [or FMT; accept feces or stool or synonyms; accept Bristol stool scale; accept stool bank]
C. diff [or Clostridioides difficile; accept Clostridium difficile or Peptoclostridium difficile; prompt on Clostridioides or Clostridium or Peptoclostridium]
parts: Identify this emerging type of treatment for Crohn's disease. The nonprofit OpenBiome banks this treatment's human-derived samples, which can be classified on the Bristol scale.

One promising use of fecal transplants is treating infections of this spore-forming bacterium, which can cause diarrhea and colitis. Infections with this Firmicutes species are often nosocomial ("no-zo-KO-mee-ul").
C. diff infection may occur after antibiotic use compromises this general phenomenon. This two-word concept describes how the endogenous microbiota prevents invasion by intestinal pathogens.

bonuses.leadin: The controversial "secondary" type of these policies bars Americans from doing business with any third parties who themselves do business with the targets of these policies. For 10 points each:
answers: BNP Paribas S.A. [or BNP Paribas S.A.; Banque Nationale de Paris]
parts: Identify these economic weapons frequently employed by the US government to target hostile regimes.
This bank, the largest in France, was fined 9 billion dollars for violating secondary sanctions in 2014.

Zimbabwe, which declared a national holiday in October 2019 to protest American sanctions, hired this lobbyist to get them off the sanctions shit-list. This member of the Harvey Weinstein defense team wrote the book Reasonable Doubts about his experience in the OJ Simpson case.

bonuses.leadin: Environmentalist Jon Marvel repeatedly overbid ranchers for leases to state-owned property in this state only for courts to rule in favor of the ranchers since Marvel was not a "qualified bidder." For 10 points each:
answers: grizzly bears [or North American brown bears; or Ursus arctos horribilis; accept Grizzly Man; prompt on brown bears or Ursidae]
parts: Identify this state whose Challis National Forest makes up part of its large River of No Return protected wilderness area.
In May 2019, Steve Bullock, then the Democratic governor of this "Big Sky" state, signed into law a bill that ended its practice of allowing conservation licenses for state-owned land.
Environmentalists tried to bid for hunting licenses for these creatures in Wyoming to film them rather than shoot them. One of these animals titles a documentary about Timothy Treadwell.

bonuses.leadin: Sociologist Paolo Gerbaudo has argued that digital technology has led to the creation of unconventional "platform parties." For 10 points each:
answers: Italy [or Italia; or Italian Republic or Repubblica Italiana] (The comedian was Beppe Grillo of the Five Star Movement.)
Marseille [or Marseilles; accept Wicked City: The Many Cultures of Marseille]
parts: It's not the UKIP, but this platform party founded by Nigel Farage cynically won 28 seats in the European Parliament despite campaigning for Britain's eponymous withdrawal from the EU.

Gerbaudo looks at the rise of a digital party in this country backed by the techno-utopian founder of Webegg. A comedian and future politician from this country organized an anti-elite "Vaffa Day" in 2007.

Gerbaudo's book profiles Jean-Luc Mélenchon ("may-lon-SHON"), who now represents this city in the National Assembly. Nicholas Hewitt's recent book on this "Wicked City" describes how its long-time mayor Gaston Defferre terrorized the Pieds-Noirs.

bonuses.leadin: In 2018 to 2019, several outlets reported on the rapid increase in people living in these things in Vancouver and Oakland. For 10 points each:
answers: vehicles [or vehicular homelessness; accept specific vehicles such as cars or vans or RVs or recreational vehicles or trailers; accept safe parking program]
Saint Paul, Minnesota [prompt on the Twin Cities]
parts: Identify these unconventional residences where over 10,000 LA residents live as part of an official "safe" program for them. People often prioritize buying these things over paying for houses and apartments because they’re often necessary to get to their jobs.

This neighborhood in the larger LA metro area, which was once known as the “slum by the sea,” cracked down on living in cars in the early 2010s. Its famous skatepark was recreated in the recent Tony Hawk’s Pro Skater remake.

This state capital waived towing and storage fees to make life easier for people living in vehicles during the COVID-19 pandemic. Its MLS team plays in Allianz Field, one of four stadiums in the same metro area designed by the firm Populous.
